cards.description: dimorphodon macronyx was discovered near lyme regis, england, on what is now called the jurassic coast. dimorphodon means “two-form tooth,” which refers to its two distinct types of teeth. macronyx refers to its large claws.
cards.name: dimorphodon macronyx

cards.description: jeholopterus was named after a city near where it was found in northeastern china. it lived in the forest, hunted insects, and is the only known species in its genus.
cards.name: jeholopterus ningchengensis

cards.description: pteranodon is one of the most famous pterosaurs, having appeared in movies such as king kong. its name means “wing without tooth” and has been found in western kansas. scientists think it may have dived for fish.
cards.name: pteranodon longiceps

cards.description: this pterosaur’s name comes from the greek word “pteron” (wing) and the latin word “auster” (south wind).  it may have used its thousands of bristle-like teeth to strain crustaceans, plankton, and other small aquatic animals.
cards.name: pterodaustro guinazui

cards.play: must be played adjacent to two different level 2 cards.
cards.description: named after both the aztec air god quetzalcoatl and the northrop corporation, this texan pterosaur had a wingspan of roughly 33 feet (the size of a 2-person airplane) and a height of 16-18 feet!
cards.effect: must be played adjacent to two different level 2 cards.
cards.name: quetzalcoatlus northropi

cards.description: tupuxuara means "long crested" and has been found along ancient south american coasts. scientists are not sure if they ate fruit or fish.
cards.name: tupuxuara leonardii

cards.description: aeger elegans is a species of shrimp found in the solnhofen limestone of germany.
cards.name: aeger elegans

cards.description: this extinct shrimp is named after the german paleontologist karl beurlen (1901-1985), who studied fossils in brazil.
cards.name: beurlenia

cards.description: these coniferous trees lived all over the globe during the jurassic and cretaceous periods.
cards.name: brachyphyllum

cards.description: the organs of clams are surrounded by watery blood that contains nutrients and oxygen.
cards.name: clam

cards.description: the fan-shaped leaves of this ancient ginkgo tree, now extinct, are similar to modern ginkgo leaves.
cards.name: ginkgo

cards.description: the fan-shaped leaves of this ancient ginkgo tree, now extinct, are similar to modern ginkgo leaves.
cards.name: ginkgo

cards.description: gnetales are an evolutionary step between cone-bearing conifers and modern flowering plants, displaying both cones and flowers.
cards.name: gnetales

cards.description: water lily fossils have been found from as early as the cretaceous period.
cards.name: nymphaeales (water lily)

cards.description: the name “paleomattae” means "ancient delicacy” and is derived from the latin word deliciosa which means delicious.
cards.name: paleomattea

cards.description: despite their large shells that could grow up to seven feet across, these predatory, squid-like shellfish were capable of swimming.
cards.name: ammonite

cards.description: cockroaches existed before pterosaurs and dinosaurs. the first fossils of modern cockroaches appeared in the early cretaceous period.
cards.name: cockroaches

cards.description: dragonflies are among the fastest and most ancient flying insects in the world!
cards.name: dragonfly

cards.description: the water strider’s long and slender legs with several thousand hairs enable them to walk on water.
cards.name: water strider

cards.description: waterscorpions are insects,  but are not closely related to true scorpions.
cards.name: waterscorpion

cards.description: waterscorpions are insects,  but are not closely related to true scorpions.
cards.name: waterscorpion

cards.description: waterscorpions are insects,  but are not closely related to true scorpions.
cards.name: waterscorpion

cards.description: n/a
cards.name: i don't think so

cards.description: in morocco, scientists found the tracks of a theropod (a type of carnivorous dinosaur) among those of pterosaurs. did dinosaurs pose a threat to pterosaurs? evidence is scarce, but some fossils suggest they did.
cards.name: theropod attack

cards.description: n/a
cards.name: home

cards.description: aspidorhynchus was a speedy, two-foot-long fish, with tooth-lined, elongated jaws.
cards.name: aspidorhynchus

cards.description: the long spine attached to the dorsal fin of the ischyodus may have been venomous.
cards.name: ischyodus

cards.description: fossils of these small freshwater fish have been found in large groups, suggesting they congregated in sandbars.
cards.name: lycoptera

cards.description: obaichthys is a primitive garfish, whose fossils have been found in brazil.
cards.name: obaichthys

cards.description: anhanguera means "old devil." the bumps on the tip of its bill may have helped it stabilize its head when snatching fish as they leapt out of the water!
cards.name: anhanguera blittersdorffi

cards.description: dsungaripterus was first found in china in the junggar basin. its jaw was not designed to catch and eat fish, but rather to dig up clams along the beach and crush them with its large flat teeth.
cards.name: dsungaripterus weii

cards.description: nyctosaurus means "night lizard." it has been found in the niobrara formation of the mid-western united states. nyctosaurus possessed an extraordinarily large antler-like crest, which is surprising given how small the pterosaur was.
cards.name: nyctosaurus gracilis

cards.description: these were the first pterosaurs ever to be identified, found in 1784 by the german scientist cosimo alessandro collini for the wonder cabinet he curated.
cards.name: pterodactylus antiquus

cards.description: rhamphorhynchus means "beak snout." this pterosaur has been found in germany. it had a very long tail, and its long, needle-like teeth helped it catch fish over open water.
cards.name: rhamphorhynchus muensteri

cards.description: scaphognathus means "fat snout" in latin. it has been found in germany and had a good sense of sight.
cards.name: scaphognathus

cards.description: tapejara means "old being" and has been found in northeast brazil. the tip of its lower jaw is turned downward. it may have been a fruit eater, or skimmed the surface of the ocean for fish.
cards.name: tapejara wellnhoferi

cards.description: the climate has shifted.
cards.name: climate change

cards.description: pterosaurs aren't immune to this fact of life: death!
cards.name: dead pterosaur

cards.description: a meteorite has crashed, disrupting the entire ecosystem! play on any level 1 or 2 card.
cards.name: meteorite crash

cards.description: the season has changed. time to move!
cards.name: migration

cards.description: a volcano has erupted, wiping out larger reptiles in this land or water area.
cards.name: volcano
